thread.title: EU Regulators Set Grace Period for New Trans-Atlantic Data Pact
thread.title_full: EU Regulators Set Grace Period for New Trans-Atlantic Data Pact

author: morningstar.com
title: EU Regulators Set Grace Period for New Trans-Atlantic Data Pact
text:
BRUSSELS—European Union privacy regulators set an end-January deadline to replace a trans-Atlantic data-transfer pact struck down by the bloc's highest court last week—and provided some certainty in the short-term for companies using other arrangements to transfer data.
The EU-U.S. agreement, known as Safe Harbor, was declared invalid last week by the European Court of Justice, which ruled that Europeans' data were insufficiently protected when landing on American soil where it could fall into the hands of U.S. national intelligence services.
The bloc's 28 national data-privacy regulators said that data transfers under Safe Harbor were now illegal. But until end-January, other arrangements for data transfers to the U.S., such as standardized contracts, could still be used.
The court decision created uncertainty for thousands of companies shifting data to the U.S., affecting billions of dollars of trade in the online advertising business, as well as more quotidian tasks such as storing users' account histories.
The ruling said national data-protection authorities had the right to override any data-transfer agreements if they found cause for concern about the way Europeans' data were being handled.
After meeting in Brussels, the EU's 28 national data-protection regulators said Friday they would look into the implications the ruling had on the other arrangements for transferring personal data.
The regulators called on the European Commission, the EU executive body, and the U.S. to find "political, legal and technical solutions" that would allow for data transfers to the U.S. in a way that respects EU citizens' privacy rights
But if by the end of January no solution is found, and depending on the regulators' assessment of the alternative data-transfer tools, the national authorities "are committed to take all necessary and appropriate actions, which may include coordinated enforcement actions," they said.
"Today's opinion should be welcomed for enabling ongoing data transfers… but we certainly aren't out of the woods yet," said Ross McKean, a data protection attorney at law firm Olswang. He said some national regulators are already hinting at a more restrictive approach to transferring data.
Even with the grace period, regulators said they still have the authority to investigate particular cases and to exercise their powers to protect citizens.
It is also unclear how much legal certainty a new transfer pact could bring firms if, as the court said in its judgment, national authorities must be able to investigate personal data transfers with "complete independence."
"The problem the court had with Safe Harbor could apply to any other way to transfer data," said Eduardo Ustaran, a privacy lawyer for tech firms at Hogan Lovells. "In theory, any legal mechanism is vulnerable to indiscriminate access to data—that is a level of uncertainty we have to live with."
For 15 years, the Safe Harbor framework allowed companies based in the U.S. to store personal data about Europeans—for instance, account details or payroll information—on U.S.-based computer servers without running afoul of Europe's strict privacy rules. In return, the companies pledged to abide by a series of EU principles, enforced by the U.S. Federal Trade Commission.
"We have been more cautious than most in the sense that we had two data-transfer mechanisms in place including Safe Harbor—but that's just a temporary safety net for us, there is a genuine uncertainty as to what will happen next," said Rene Summer, a government and industry relations director at Swedish telecommunications company Ericsson AB.
Meanwhile, political pressure is ramping up on the European Commission to adhere to strict privacy principles in its negotiations over the new data-transfer pact with the U.S. Lawmakers at the European Parliament this week passed a resolution saying too little had been done to ensure that European citizens are protected from electronic mass surveillance.
Ensuring privacy in commercial transactions "is a very basic thing, this is not some kind of outlandish human rights request," said Claude Moraes, chairman of the Parliament's civil liberties committee, in response to the ECJ ruling.
"We can see now a scramble, certainly in the United States, for companies who were pretending that everything was okay."
Sam Schechner contributed to this article.
